items.title: Lainey Wilson Is â€˜Keepinâ€™ Country Coolâ€™ With a New Documentary: Hereâ€™s When ItÂ Arrives
items.summary: The project will go behind the scenes of the triumphs and struggles as she continues building her brand.
items.body: Lainey Wilson’ s current status as an arena headliner, the reigning CMA entertainer of the year winner and Billboard charting hitmaker will be explored through a new Netflix documentary. â€œI couldnâ€™t be more excited that this documentary is going to be on Netflix,” she said in a statement. “This was such a special project to make, and I hope that folks who watch it see that no dream is too big and that staying true to who you are will always lead you exactly where youâ€™re meant to be.” Lainey Wilson: Keepin’ Country Cool , directed by Amy Scott ( Sheryl , Counting Crows: Have You Seen Me Lately? ), will premiere globally on Netflix on April 22. The film will capture Wilson during a pivotal time during her career, chronicling her journey as well as her triumphs and struggles as she continues building her multi-faceted career as a songwriter, hitmaker, entertainer, actress and businesswoman. The documentary is produced by Angus Wall, Terry Leonard, Kent Kubena, Thomas Tull, Jillian Share, Jason Owen and Jen Gorton, while Mandelyn Monchick, Josh Miller, Katie Admire, Jillian Apfelbaum and Nicolas Gordon serve as executive producers on the project. Lainey Wâ€¦

items.title: How Jody Gerson Has Made Publishing â€˜The Hot Businessâ€™ RightÂ Now
items.summary: Since 2015, Billboard's Executive of the Decade has reigned as the most powerful woman in the business â€” boosting UMPG's revenue and championing songwriters at every step of the way.
items.body: On a sunny morning in October, Universal Music Publishing Group chairman/CEO Jody Gerson gathered her lieutenants around a table in her Santa Monica, Calif., office, Zooming in her overseas executives on a big screen, and proudly Â­introduced what she described as evidence to inform the Â­ongoing industry discussion on â€œwhether AI will replace human artistry.â€ â€œIâ€™m going to show you why it will not,â€ Gerson said, clad in a black leather jacket and her signature rose-tinted aviator glasses, cueing the dazzlingly original video for the operatic track â€œBerghainâ€ that had just been released by RosalÃ­a, whom Gerson signed in 2019 and has worked with closely ever since. â€œThe reaction that this videoâ€™s getting just gives me hope that real artists will prevail.â€ Related How RosalÃ­a Crafted Her Wildly Ambitious Album While Filming â€˜Euphoriaâ€™: â€˜For Some Reason, I Didnâ€™t Completely Go Crazyâ€™ Billboard Announces Lineup of Exclusive 2026 Grammy Week Events INXS, AC/DC, GANGgajang Lead Triple M's Most Played Songs in Network History Throughout the rest of the meeting, as each team member gave their updates, Gerson interjected frequently to offer support, asking if there was â€œanythiâ€¦

items.title: Protoje & Chronixx to Headline 2026 Lost in TimeÂ Festival
items.summary: Set for Kingston, Jamaica, the two-day festival promises a star-studded lineup.
items.body: Protoje’s Lost in Time Festival is back and bigger than ever. Related The Ultimate Guide to Festivals Celebrating Caribbean Music in 2026 (Updating) The 10 Best Caribbean Albums of 2025 (Critic’s Picks) ‘Jamaica Strong’ Hurricane Melissa Relief Benefit Concert Heats Up New York City: 5 Best Moments Billboard can exclusively announce that the Grammy-nominated reggae star’s festival will return to Hope Gardens in Kingston, Jamaica, on Feb. 28 and March 1. Gearing up for its third iteration, the multi-stage festival will bring together leaders across music, art, food and culture for an extravaganza celebrating Jamrock’s resilience. Fans can purchase tickets via the festival’s website . Protoje, who recently dropped a new Damian Marley-assisted single titled “At We Feet,” will headline Saturday night (Feb. 28), which will also include performances by 2026 Grammy nominees Lila IkÃ© and Mortimer, as well as Tanya Stephens, Tessanne Chin, Yeza, Iotosh and Joby Jay. Chronixx, whose Exile was named the No. 1 Caribbean Album of 2025 by Billboard , will headline Sunday night (March 1), delivering his first live performance since â€¦

items.title: Hereâ€™s Who Will Headline the Atlanta Bravesâ€™ First CountryÂ Fest
items.summary: The daylong festival will take place June 13.
items.body: The Atlanta Braves are trading in bats for guitars on June 13. The baseball team, in conjunction with Live Nation, will host the inaugural Braves Country Fest at their home stadium, Truist Park. Related Cody Johnson Scores His Highest Hot Country Songs Debut With ‘Travelin’ Soldier’ Ella Langley Announces Sophomore Album ‘Dandelion’: ‘I’ve Never Poured More of Myself Into a Project’ How Rare Is It for a Country Song by a Woman to Reach the Top 10 of the Hot 100? Headliner Cody Johnson will be joined by Ella Langley , ERNEST and MacKenzie Carpenter at the Truist-sponsored event. The paid concert will cap a daylong festival with free activations and performances at The Battery Atlanta. Performing at the Braves Country Hot Prospects showcase at the Whiskey Jam stage at the Georgia Power Pavilion at the Battery Atlanta will be hot newcomers Zach John King, Scoot Teasley and Colton Bowlin. â€œIt has been our goal to create Atlanta Braves experiences that extend beyond the game of baseball, and Braves Country Fest presented by Truist will be an incredible celebration of the rich country music culture that permeates throughout Braveâ€¦

items.title: Spotify Touts $11 Billion Paid to Music Industry, Addresses StreamingÂ Criticism
items.summary: "Despite rampant misinformation... the reality is that this is an era full of more success stories ... than at any point in history," says Spotify's global head of music.
items.body: Spotify’s global head of music, Charlie Hellman , released a letter to users on Wednesday (Jan. 28), highlighting the platform’s contributions to the music industry ahead of its famous Best New Artist Grammy party in Los Angeles. “Spotify paid out more than $11 billion to the music industry, the largest annual payment to music from any retailer in history,” he writes, noting that indie artists and labels accounted for over half of those royalties. Hellman notes that “there are now more artists generating over $100k/year from Spotify alone than were getting stocked on record store shelves at the height of the CD era,” but he says that “rampant misinformation” about streaming has led the public to distrust how successful and lucrative these services have been for musicians. Related Spotify Confirms U.S. Price Hike for Premium Plans Starting Soon INXS, AC/DC, GANGgajang Lead Triple M's Most Played Songs in Network History Maya J'an Signs With Warner Records: Debut Single is a Powerful 'Love Letter' to Hometown After L.A. Fires The letter highlights that Spotify pays two-thirds of its music revenue back to the inâ€¦

items.title: Darren Criss to Host & Perform at 2026 Grammy PremiereÂ Ceremony
items.summary: Zara Larsson, Spiritbox, Tasha Cobbs Leonard, Maggie Rose, Grace Potter & more are also scheduled to perform.
items.body: First-time Grammy nominee Darren Criss will host and perform at the 2026 Grammy Awards Premiere Ceremony, where the bulk of this year’s Grammys will be handed out ahead of the prime-time telecast. The event will be held at Peacock Theater in Los Angeles on Sunday, Feb. 1, and will stream live at 3:30 p.m. ET/12:30 p.m. PT on the Recording Academyâ€™s YouTube channel and on live.GRAMMY.com . Related Darren Criss & RenÃ©e Elise Goldsberry to Cohost ‘The Tony Awards: Act One’ Darren Criss and Helen J. Shen Talk Finding Their ‘Maybe Happy Ending’ on Broadway: ‘It’s a Really Charming, Kind Little World’ Chris Colfer Celebrates Former ‘Glee’ Love Interest Darren Criss Winning a Tony: ‘So Proud of You’ Criss will perform with Helen J. Shen, his co-star in the Broadway musical Maybe Happy Ending . The show won six Tony Awards in June, including two for Criss: best leading actor in a musical and as a producer of the best musical winner. The cast album is nominated for a Grammy as best musical show album. If it wins, Criss will be just an Oscar away from EGOT status. He won a Primetime Emmy in 2018 for hâ€¦

items.title: Rihanna Said Super Relatable Thing About How Fashion Choices Changed Since Becoming Mom of Three: â€˜I Wanted Skirts With a LittleÂ Bumpâ€™
items.summary: The singer talked about the "little pouch" she has after welcoming three children with partner A$AP Rocky.
items.body: Rihanna is a billionaire international pop star and beauty/fashion mogul. But during an interview with Dior during Paris’ Haute Couture Fashion Week, she said she said something every new mom could relate to when gushing about the fashion house’s spring/summer collection show. In an interview posted on TikTok on Monday (Jan. 26) the “Love on the Brain” singer said she looks for a very specific silhouette after having three kids with longtime partner A$AP Rocky . â€œI wanted the coats, I wanted the dresses, I wanted the skirts with a little bump right here [at the stomach] â€˜cause I got a little pouch after having kids, so Iâ€™d love that,” said the 37-year-old singer who is mother to sons RZA, 3, and Riot, 2 and four-month old baby daughter Rocki. â€œI loved the accessories â€” the bags, the shoes, the earrings â€” everything was perfectly made, super well done, super whimsical. Everything made me excited. It was a very thrilling show,” she added. Though the couple are still settling in with their latest bundle of joy, some fans thought that RihRih slyly hinted that she might be ready to think about busting out the maternity wear again when she gave a provâ€¦

items.title: Morgan Wade, Carter Faith Latest Artists To Bail on Rock the CountryÂ Tour
items.summary: They follow Ludacris, whose reps said he "wasn't supposed" to be on the lineup in the first place.
items.body: Two more acts have quietly exited the MAGA-coded Rock the Country tour festival. After initially appearing on the tour’s lineup poster alongside headliners Kid Rock and Jason Aldean, country singers Morgan Wade and Carter Faith appear to have dropped off the bill. While at press time neither act had commented on their departure on their socials, Rolling Stone reported that sources close to both acts confirmed that they will not be performing on the tour. The magazine said that on Friday (Jan. 23) Wade’s name vanished from the tour poster and Faith responded to a fan asking why she was on the bill with an, “I’m not anymore!” At press time a spokesperson for the festival had not responded to Billboard ‘s request for comment. The tour, which bills itself as “a festival for the people… celebrating 250 years of freedom” in this year of the nation’s semiquincentennial, is slated to hit eight tertiary markets in towns such as Ashland, Ky., Bloomingdale, Ga. and Hastings, Mich., with a lineup that also includes Jelly Roll, Creed, Brooks and Dunn, Miranda Lambert, Hank Williams Jr., Shinedown, Ella Langley, Jon Pardi, Nelly, Uncleâ€¦

items.title: Oppo returns to Germany with Find X9 and other phones now on sale
items.summary: After years of absence, Oppo has finally returned to Germany with several of its latest smartphones, including the Find X9 series, now available for purchase. moreâ€¦

items.title: 'I'm always the chaser?' - Djokovic unimpressed by reporter's question
items.summary: 24-time Grand Slam winner Novak Djokovic says he felt "disrespectful" after being asked how he felt "chasing" Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, after previously "chasing" Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal during the early parts of his career.

items.title: Fresh or undercooked? Djokovic unsure where fortune leaves him

items.title: Webb Data Reveals Dark Matter
items.summary: This image from NASAâ€™s James Webb Space Telescope, containing nearly 800,000 galaxies, is overlaid with a map of dark matter, represented in blue. Brighter blue areas indicate a higher density of dark matter. Researchers used Webb data to find the dark matter â€” which is invisible â€” via its gravitatâ€¦
items.body: 3 Min Read Webb Data Reveals Dark Matter PIA26702 Credits: NASA/STScI/J. DePasquale/A. Pagan Photojournal Navigation Science Photojournal Webb Data Reveals Dark Matter Photojournal Home Photojournal Search Latest Content Galleries Feedback RSS About Downloads Webb Data Reveals Dark Matter PNG (42.87 MB) This image from NASAâ€™s James Webb Space Telescope, containing nearly 800,000 galaxies, is overlaid with a map of dark matter, represented in blue. Brighter blue areas indicate a higher density of dark matter. Researchers used Webb data to find the dark matter â€” which is invisible â€” via its gravitational influence on regular matter. The area of sky shown here is 0.54 square degrees (about 2Â½ times the size of the full Moon) and located in the constellation Sextans. Webbâ€™s Near-Infrared Camera (NIRCam) peered at this region for a total of about 255 hours. Dark matter doesnâ€™t emit, reflect, absorb, or even block light, and is therefore not visible to the human eye or traditional telescopes. But it does interact with the universe through gravity, and large clumps or clusters of dark matter have enough mass to curve space itself. Light traveling to Earth from distant galaxies becomes slâ€¦

items.body: 5 min read Preparations for Next Moonwalk Simulations Underway (and Underwater) Jupiterâ€™s moon Europa was captured by the JunoCam instrument aboard NASAâ€™s Juno spacecraft during the missionâ€™s close flyby on Sept. 29, 2022. The images show the fractures, ridges, and bands that crisscross the moonâ€™s surface. Image data: NASA/JPL-Caltech/SwRI/MSSS Image processing: BjÃ¶rn JÃ³nsson (CC BY 3.0) Results from the solar-powered spacecraft provide a new measurement of the thickness of the ice shell encasing the Jovian moonâ€™s ocean .   Data from NASAâ€™s Juno mission has provided new insights into the thickness and subsurface structure of the icy shell encasing Jupiterâ€™s moon Europa. Using the spacecraftâ€™s Microwave Radiometer (MWR), mission scientists determined that the shell averages about 18 miles (29 kilometers) thick in the region observed during Junoâ€™s 2022 flyby of Europa. The Juno measurement is the first to discriminate between thin and thick shell models that have suggested the ice shell is anywhere from less than half a mile to tens of miles thick.   Slightly smaller than Earthâ€™s moon, Europa is one of the solar systemâ€¦

items.body: 3 min read Preparations for Next Moonwalk Simulations Underway (and Underwater) Athena, NASAâ€™s newest supercomputer, is housed at the agencyâ€™s Modular Supercomputing Facility at NASAâ€™s Ames Research Center in Californiaâ€™s Silicon Valley. NASA/Brandon Torres-Navarrete NASA is announcing the availability of its newest supercomputer, Athena, an advanced system designed to support a new generation of missions and research projects. The newest member of the agencyâ€™s High-End Computing Capability project expands the resources available to help scientists and engineers tackle some of the most complex challenges in space, aeronautics, and science. Housed in the agencyâ€™s Modular Supercomputing Facility at NASAâ€™s Ames Research Center in Californiaâ€™s Silicon Valley, Athena delivers more computing power than any other NASA system, surpassing the capabilities of its predecessors, Aitken and Pleiades, in power and efficiency. The new system, which was rolled out in January to existing users after a beta testing period, delivers over 20 petaflops of peak performance â€“ a measurement of the number of calculations it can make per second â€“ while reducing the agencyâ€™s supercomputing utility costs. â€œEâ€¦

items.title: NASAâ€™s James Webb Space Telescope Finds Crystal-Spewing Protostar
items.summary: The NIRCam (Near-Infrared Camera) on NASAâ€™s James Webb Space Telescope captured the actively forming protostar EC 53 (circled at left) in the Serpens Nebula in this image released on Jan. 21, 2026. Astronomers have long sought evidence to explain why comets at the outskirts of our own solar system â€¦
items.body: NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI, Klaus Pontoppidan (NASA-JPL), Joel Green (STScI); Image Processing: Alyssa Pagan (STScI) The NIRCam (Near-Infrared Camera) on NASAâ€™s James Webb Space Telescope captured the actively forming protostar EC 53 (circled at left) in the Serpens Nebula in this image released on Jan. 21, 2026. Astronomers have long sought evidence to explain why  comets  at the outskirts of our own  solar system  contain crystalline silicates, since crystals require intense heat to form and these â€œdirty snowballsâ€ spend most of their time in the ultracold Kuiper Belt and Oort Cloud. Now, looking outside our solar system, Webb has returned the first conclusive evidence that links how those conditions are possible. The telescope clearly showed for the first time that the hot, inner part of the disk of gas and dust surrounding a very young, actively forming star is where crystalline silicates are forged. Webb also revealed a strong outflow that is capable of carrying the crystals to the outer edges of this disk. Compared to our own fully formed, mostly dust-cleared solar system, the crystals would be forming approximately between the Sun and Earth. Reâ€¦

items.title: NASA, Partners Advance LISA Prototype Hardware
items.summary: Engineers and scientists at NASAâ€™s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, completed tests this month on a second early version of a key element of the upcoming LISA (Laser Interferometer Space Antenna) mission. The LISA mission, a collaboration between ESA (the European Space Agency) aâ€¦
items.body: 3 min read NASA, Partners Advance LISA Prototype Hardware Engineers and scientists at NASAâ€™s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, completed tests this month on a second early version of a key element of the upcoming LISA (Laser Interferometer Space Antenna) mission. The LISA mission , a collaboration between ESA (the European Space Agency) and NASA, will use infrared lasers to detect gravitational waves , or ripples in the fabric of space-time. The tests involved the frequency reference system, delivered by BAE Systems, that will help control the lasers connecting LISAâ€™s three spacecraft. The lasers must be finely tuned to make precise measurements â€” to within a trillionth of a meter, called a picometer. A prototype laser optical module for LISA (Laser Interferometer Space Antenna) rests on a table after testing at NASAâ€™s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, in May 2025. Xiaozhen Xu, an engineer with Miller Engineering and Research Corp., works in the background. The smaller box to the right is the laser electronics module. Each of the three LISA spacecraft will have a laser system with a frequency reference component and six laser heads. NASA/Sophia â€¦

items.title: Booze, beach, beaten - how England lost the Ashes
items.summary: BBC Sport chief cricket reporter Stephan Shemilt reveals the inside story of England's Ashes defeat in Australia on and off the pitch.

items.title: WHO validates Brazil for eliminating mother-to-child transmission of HIV
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has validated Brazil for the elimination of mother-to-child transmission (EMTCT) of HIV, making it the most populous country in the Americas to achieve this historic milestone. This accomplishment reflects Brazilâ€™s long-standing commitment to universal and free aâ€¦

items.title: I've realised I can make a difference - Hoy
items.summary: In a new BBC documentary, Sir Chris Hoy shows how he is using his Olympic mindset to reframe his purpose following a terminal cancer diagnosis.

items.title: WHO expert groupâ€™s new analysis reaffirms there is no link between vaccines and autism
items.summary: New analysis from a WHO global expert committee on vaccine safety has found that, based on available evidence, no causal link exists between vaccines and autism spectrum disorders (ASD). The conclusion reaffirms WHOâ€™s position that childhood vaccines do not cause autism.

items.title: The man behind the headlines - Salah, by Klopp, Diaz and more
items.summary: BBC Sport explores Mohamed Salah's personality with help from the people who know him best.

items.title: Inside McLaren's season - the rules, values, incidents & relationships
items.summary: Intra-team title battles turn toxic far more often than not. Andrew Benson analyses how McLaren have maintained relative harmony between Lando Norris and Oscar Piastri.

items.title: Most countries make progress towards universal health coverage, but major challenges remain, WHOâ€“World Bank report finds
items.summary: Since 2000, most countries â€“ across all income levels and regions â€“ have made concurrent progress in expanding health service coverage and reducing the financial hardship associated with health costs, according to a new joint report from the World Health Organization (WHO) and the World Bank Group.â€¦

items.title: Countries to reconvene sooner to accelerate progress on WHO Pathogen Access and Benefit Sharing system negotiations
items.summary: WHO Member States today ended their latest round of intensive negotiations on the worldâ€™s first Pathogen Access andBenefit Sharing (PABS) system. Countries decided to resume deliberations in January in a reflection of the shared commitment and urgency needed to help make the world safer from futureâ€¦

items.title: England's AI World Cup masterplan - from perfecting penalties to powering players
items.summary: BBC Sport hears from inside the England setup about how artificial intelligence is powering plans for next summer's World Cup.

items.title: New tools saved a million lives from malaria last year but progress under threat as drug resistance rises
items.summary: This yearâ€™s report provides a critical and up-to-date snapshot of efforts to control and eliminate malaria across 80 countries. The report also presents the threat posed by antimalarial resistance and its impact.

items.title: WHO issues global guideline on the use of GLP-1 medicines in treating obesity
items.summary: To address the growing global health challenge of obesity, which affects more than 1 billion people, WHO has released its first guideline on the use of Glucagon-Like Peptide-1 (GLP-1) therapies for treating obesity as a chronic, relapsing disease.

items.title: New prevention tools and investment in services essential in the fight against AIDS
items.summary: On World AIDS Day, the World Health Organization (WHO) calls on governments and partners to rapidly expand access to new WHO-approved tools including lenacapavir (LEN) to drive down infections and counter disruption to essential health services caused by cuts to foreign aid. items.title: WHO issues first global guideline on infertility
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) today called on countries to make fertility care safer, fairer and more affordable for all in its first-ever global guideline for the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of infertility.Infertility is estimated to affect 1 in 6 people of reproductive age at some pâ€¦

items.title: Measles deaths down 88% since 2000, but cases surge
items.summary: Global immunization efforts have led to an 88% drop in measles deaths between 2000 and 2024, according to a new report from the World Health Organization (WHO). Nearly 59 million lives have been saved by the measles vaccine since 2000.

items.title: Lifetime toll: 840 million women faced partner or sexual violence
items.summary: Violence against women remains one of the worldâ€™s most persistent and under-addressed human rights crises, with very little progress in two decades, according to a landmark report released today by the World Health Organization (WHO) and UN partners. items.title: More countries report rising levels of drug-resistant gonorrhoea, warns WHO
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that gonorrhoea, a sexually transmitted infection, is becoming increasingly resistant to antibiotics, according to new data from its Enhanced Gonococcal Antimicrobial Surveillance Programme (EGASP), which monitors the spread of drug-resistant gonorrhoea. Thâ€¦

items.title: World marks cervical cancer elimination day as countries accelerate action
items.summary: Today marks the first World Cervical Cancer Elimination Day â€“ mandated by the World Health Assembly â€“ a historic milestone in global efforts to end a preventable cancer.

items.title: WHO promotes lifesaving intervention for small and preterm babies on first official World Prematurity Day
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is marking its first official observance of World Prematurity Day with the launch of a new global clinical practice guide for Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) â€“ a simple, proven and life-saving intervention that significantly improves survival for preterm and low birthâ€¦

items.title: WHO launches global guidelines on diabetes during pregnancy on World Diabetes Day
items.summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) today released its first global guidelines for the management of diabetes during pregnancy, a condition affecting about one in six pregnancies â€“ or 21 million women annually.
